projectDesc.p: "漁家傲" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “the Fisherman is Proud”
One suddenly hears the strike of the two oars under the flowers;
instantly the girlfriends come to visit.
The lotus leaves immediately turn into wine cups.
Among the lotuses, the boat swings;
in the cups red waves surge on and on.
The aroma of the flowers and the wine brew freshness.
The flower-like cheeks and wine-tinted faces redden toward each other.
Tipsy, they lean on the green shade to have a good nap.
Startled to awaken, they rise to look:
the head of the boat is stranded on the beach.
